name: Total Charitable Giving
description: Charitable giving can occur through many different avenues for generosity. Here, we use one measure of aggregate charitable giving, which includes contributions from individuals, corporations, bequests, and foundations.

measures.name: Total charitable contributions
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulations of tax data, economic indicators, and demographics.

name: Individual giving
description: Individuals, as opposed to institutions, have long represented the largest source of charitable giving in the United States. Giving by the ultra-wealthy continues to represent a disproportionately large share of giving by individuals.

measures.name: Share of total charitable contributions made by individuals
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax, data, economic indicators, and demographics.

measures.name: Total charitable contributions made by individuals
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax, data, economic indicators, and demographics.

measures.name: Share of charitable contributions made by ultra-wealthy individuals
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated by WealthX’s Philanthropic Giving Model, which analyzes the annual philanthropic donations made by ultra-wealthy individuals in each market (those with a net worth of more than $30 million). WealthX then uses its proprietary Wealth and Investable Assets Model to estimate total philanthropic giving (as a proportion of total wealth) in each region. These figures exclude giving by corporations as well as businesses owned by the ultra-wealthy.

measures.name: Share of charitable donations lessthan $5,001
measures.notes: Estimates are based on GivingTuesday’s Growth in Giving dataset, which is a longitudinal database of donation transactions by individuals in the US aggregated from many sources (including customer relationship management databases and other giving platforms). Transactions included in this database are limited to those made to 501(c)3s with no more than $25M in contributions and with data from three consecutive years.

name: Noncash Charitable Contributions
description: Not all giving comes in the form of cash. Many organizations accept non-cash assets, including publicly traded securities (stocks, bonds and mutual funds) and non-publicly traded assets (private stock, restricted stock, and limited partnership interests). These contributions can be itemized on taxpayers’ yearly tax returns.

measures.name: Total annual value of noncash charitable contributions
measures.source: IRS SOI Tax Stats: Individual Income Tax Returns Complete Report
measures.notes: Noncash (or “other than cash”) charitable contributions are calculated by the IRS Statistics of Income Division, aggregating data from itemized individual tax returns.

measures.name: Share of non-cash assets among all itemized charitable contributions
measures.source: IRS SOI Tax Stats: Individual Income Tax Returns Complete Report
measures.notes: Noncash (or “other than cash”) charitable contributions are calculated by the IRS Statistics of Income Division, aggregating data from itemized individual tax returns.

name: Volunteering
description: Volunteering is a core component of how individuals express generosity. Much of the data on volunteering registers how individuals help tax-exempt nonprofit institutions, but volunteers can also assist informal organizations and association.

measures.name: Share of Americans who volunteer
measures.source: Bureau of Labor Statisticsand Corporation for National and Community Service
measures.notes: Estimates pulled from the Current Population Survey Volunteering and Civic Life Supplement. This supplement was administered by the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 2002-2015 and recently transitioned to the Corporation for National and Community Service starting in 2017. The count of volunteers only includes persons who volunteered through or for an organization. The figures do not include persons who volunteered in a more informal manner.

measures.name: Total hours volunteered
measures.notes: Estimates pulled from the Current Population Survey Volunteering and Civic Life Supplement. This supplement was administered by the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 2002-2015 and recently transitioned to the Corporation for National and Community Service (CNCS) starting in 2017. The count of volunteers only includes persons who volunteered through or for an organization. The figures do not include persons who volunteered in a more informal manner.

name: Impact investing
description: Impact investments intentionally seek social and environmental impact as well as financial returns and offer a way beyond charitable giving for individuals and institutions to have an impact.

measures.name: Share of affluent households who participate in impact investing
measures.source: Bank of America/IUPUI Lilly School of Philanthropy
measures.notes: Estimates are based on 2021 nationally representative random sample of 1,626 high-net-worth households and includes in-depth analysis based on age, gender, race, and sexual identity by IUPUI’s Lilly School of Philanthropy. High-net-worth households are defined as households with a net worth of $1M+ and/or have an annual income of $200,000+.

measures.name: Total DAF assets in impact investment pools at Fidelity Charitable
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated using data from 153,430 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database.

measures.name: Total amount of recoverable grantsby Fidelity Charitable DAFs to charities
measures.notes: Recoverable grants are donations that can be repaid under some circumstances. Estimates are calculated using data from 153,430 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database. Most recent study conducted January-December 2020.

name: Political giving
description: Traditionally, giving to political campaigns has not been considered a form of charitable giving. But the lines between political and charitable giving are becoming increasingly blurred through giving vehicles such as limited liability companies. Donations to party-focused organizations such as WinRed or ActBlue as well as donations to individual candidates or campaigns comprise political giving. (Gifts to 501(c)4s or political action committees are not included in this summary.)

measures.name: Total donors that gave over $200 to a political campaign
measures.notes: Estimates are taken from the Federal Election Commission, aggregated every calendar year (January-December). Fluctuations in political donations year-to-year are partially attributable to election cycles (e.g., presidential election years vs. off-year elections).

measures.name: Total money contributed to political campaigns from donations over $200
measures.notes: Estimates are taken from the Federal Election Commission, aggregated every calendar year (January-December). Fluctuations in political donations year-to-year are in part attributable to election cycles (e.g., presidential election years vs. off-year elections).

measures.name: Money donated to WinRed
measures.notes: An online donation platform launched in June 2019, WinRed allows individuals to donate to Republican candidates and campaigns nationwide. Estimates include aggregate annual donations made to political campaigns using WinRed’s platform.

measures.name: Money donated to ActBlue
measures.notes: An online donation platform launched in 2004, ActBlue allows individuals to donate to Democratic candidates and campaigns nationwide. Estimates include aggregate annual donations made to political campaigns using ActBlue’s platform.

name: Giving by Bequest
description: Charitable bequests, which are tax-deductible gifts through a will or trust, can come in many forms and represent a significant share of total charitable contributions.

measures.name: Total giving by bequest
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax, data, economic indicators, and demographics.

measures.name: Share of total charitable contributions given through bequest
measures.notes: Estimates rely on econometrics methods developed by Indiana University Lilly Family School of Philanthropy and tabulation of tax, data, economic indicators, and demographics

name: Donor-Advised Funds
description: Donor-advised funds (DAFs) are giving accounts established at public charities that allow donors to make a charitable contribution, receive an immediate tax deduction, and recommend grants over time. The public charity maintains legal control over the contributions and works with the donor who can advise on funding recommendations.

measures.name: Total value of contributions made to donor-advised funds
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a longitudinal study of a representative sample from 976 charitable sponsors that reported DAF assets in any year.

measures.name: Total number of DAFs in the US
measures.notes: Estimates are drawn from a longitudinal study of a representative sample from 976 charitable sponsors that reported DAF assets in any year.

measures.name: Share of DAF contributions made as noncash assets at Fidelity Charitable
measures.notes: Estimates are calculated using data from about 154,430 giving accounts in Fidelity Charitable’s internal reporting database.

measures.name: Total dollars contributed to DAFs at community foundations
measures.notes: Estimates are sourced from a non-representative survey of 84 US community foundations. Study conducted between late 2020 and early 2021.
